 |calling_code = +595 |cctld = .py |footnote_a = Mixed European and Amerindian.
 }} 'Paraguay' (US , UK ), officially the 'Republic of Paraguay' ( , GuaranÃ­:
 TetÃ£ ParaguÃ¡i ), is a landlocked country in South America, bordered by
 Argentina to the south and southwest, Brazil to the east and northeast, and
 Bolivia to the northwest. Paraguay lies on both banks of the Paraguay River,
 which runs through the center of the country from north to south. Due to its
 central location in South America, it is sometimes referred to as CorazÃ³n de
 AmÃ©rica ("Heart of America").

The indigenous GuaranÃ­ have been living in Paraguay since at least 1,000 years
before the Spanish colonial empire conquered the territory in the 16th century.
Jesuits introduced Christianity, and a syncretic form of Catholicism developed
that absorbed some indigenous traditions. Jesuit Reductions relocated Indians to
local communities near missions. Following independence from Spain in 1811,
Paraguay was ruled by a series of dictators who implemented isolationist and
protectionist policies. Development was truncated by the disastrous Paraguayan
War (1864â1870), in which the country lost 60% to 70% of its population through
war and disease, and about of territory to Argentina and Brazil.

In the 20th century, Paraguay endured a succession of authoritarian governments,
culminating in the regime of Alfredo Stroessner, who led South America's longest-
lived uninterrupted military dictatorship from 1954 to 1989. He was toppled in
an internal military coup, and free multi-party elections were organized and
held for the first time in 1993. A year later, Paraguay joined Argentina, Brazil
and Uruguay to found Mercosur, a regional economic collaborative.

As of 2009, Paraguay's population was estimated to be at around 6.5 million,
most of whom are concentrated in the southeast region of the country. The
capital and largest city is AsunciÃ³n, of which the metropolitan area is home to
nearly a third of the Paraguay's population. In contrast to most Latin American
nations, Paraguay's population widely uses indigenous language and the GuaranÃ­
culture is highly influential. In censuses, the residents predominately identify
as mestizo, reflecting years of intermarriage among the different cultures.
GuaranÃ­ is recognized as an official language alongside Spanish. Both languages
are widely spoken in the country, with around 92% of the general population
speaking Spanish and 98% speaking GuaranÃ­.

Paraguay has long been one of the region's poorest and most isolated countries.
Since the turn of the 21st century, it has had rapid economic growth. In 2010,
the economy grew by 14.5%, the largest economic expansion in Latin America, and
the third fastest in the world (after Qatar and Singapore). CIA By
2011, economic growth had slowed to 6.4%, but remained far higher than the
global average. Widespread poverty, socioeconomic
inequality, and poor governance remain persistent challenges.
